thread.title: FC Dallas wins to take lead in West standings
thread.title_full: FC Dallas wins to take lead in West standings | The Seattle Times

author: Seattle Times staff
title: FC Dallas wins to take lead in West standings
text:
Soccer FC Dallas wins to lead West Mauro Diaz had a goal and an assist, and host FC Dallas beat the Vancouver Whitecaps 2-0 on Wednesday night to grab sole possession of first place in the Western Conference.
FC Dallas (16-10-6) has 54 points and is tied with the New York Red Bulls atop Major League Soccer’s Supporters’ Shield standings. Vancouver (15-13-5) is in third place with 50 points, one point behind the Los Angeles Galaxy.
Fanendo Adi scored on a penalty kick in the 54th minute, and the Portland Timbers beat 10-man host Real Salt Lake 1-0 for their third straight road win in the series.
Portland (13-11-8) moved into a tie with Seattle for fifth in the Western Conference with 47 points. Real Salt Lake (11-13-8) is tied for eighth, six points back of the Timbers.

Daniels, RB Rod Smith Ana Mari Cauce new UW president; popular on, off campus USC fires head coach Steve Sarkisian, former UW Huskies coach Seattle council candidate alleges shakedown by developer Truck wrecks cause huge I-5 backups during morning rush Unlimited Digital Access. $1 for 4 weeks. Sebastian Giovinco scored his 22nd goal of the season, and host Toronto FC beat the New York Red Bulls 2-1 to clinch its first playoff appearance.
It was the fourth straight win for Toronto FC (15-13-4), which is headed to the playoffs for the first time after joining MLS in 2006.
Shaun Wright-Phillips scored for New York (16-10-6) in the 86th minute. The Red Bulls are five points ahead of Toronto FC for first place in the East with two games remaining on their schedule.
Tennis Bouchard sues USTA Canadian star Eugenie Bouchard filed a lawsuit against the United States Tennis Association that alleges the sport’s national governing body was negligent, leaving her to slip and fall in a locker room during the U.S. Open.
Bouchard, who was a runner-up at Wimbledon last year, has suffered severe pain and economic loss after the Sept. 4 incident, she said in the federal lawsuit filed in U.S. District Court in Brooklyn that seeks unspecified monetary damages.
Golf NCAA champ leaves SMU U.S. Amateur champion Bryson DeChambeau has left Southern Methodist after the NCAA imposed penalties against the men’s golf team that would keep him from defending his NCAA individual title next summer.
DeChambeau last summer joined Jack Nicklaus, Phil Mickelson, Tiger Woods and Ryan Moore of Puyallup as the only players to win the U.S. Amateur and NCAA individual titles in the same year.
According to Golf Channel, DeChambeau plans to play the Argentina Open and Australian Open in November, and is expected to turn pro after the Masters.
Rory McIlroy is starting a new season on the PGA Tour before finishing his other season on the European Tour.
McIlroy is the star attraction at the Frys.com Open, which starts Thursday at Silverado in Napa, Calif., to kick off a new season on the PGA Tour. And to think it has been all of 17 days since Jordan Spieth ended the previous season as the FedEx Cup champion.
McIlroy is at Silverado because he was among eight players who took part in an exhibition in Turkey three years ago that was held the same week as this PGA Tour event. They agreed to play the Frys.com Open once over the next three years.
ELSEWHERE • Colombian soccer coach Juan Carlos Osorio took charge of Mexico’s national men’s team, becoming the 12th person to lead “El Tri” in the past nine years. Osorio replaces interim coach Ricardo Ferretti , who had been in the job since Miguel Herrera was fired in July after he punched a TV reporter at an airport following Mexico’s victory at the CONCACAF Gold Cup.
• Novak Djokovic of Serbia extended his winning streak to 13 straight matches with a swift 6-2, 6-1 win over Martin Klizan of Slovakia in the second round of the Shanghai Masters. Rafael Nadal of Spain escaped with a 7-5, 6-7 (4-7), 7-6 (7-4) win over Ivo Karlovic of Croatia.
• Jelena Jankovic of Serbia and Samantha Stosur of Australia advanced to the quarterfinals of the Hong Kong Open. Jankovic beat Anastasia Rodionova of Australia 6-0, 6-2. Stosur defeated Monica Puig of Puerto Rico 6-4, 6-4.
• Caroline Wozniacki of Denmark was the only player among the top five seeded women to reach the second round at the Generali Ladies in Linz, Austria, rallying to beat Mirjana Lucic-Baroni of Croatia 3-6, 7-6 (7-3), 6-4.
• CBS Sports filled a big void on its golf broadcasting team by hiring Dottie Pepper , giving the network that covers the most PGA Tour events its first female voice. She replaces David Feherty , who left CBS to join NBC Sports.
• Washington Capitals star Alex Ovechkin said he overslept and missed practice Tuesday morning, and that’s why coach Barry Trotz made him sit out that night’s game against the San Jose Sharks.
• Construction will begin next year for the new U.S. National Soccer Hall of Fame and Museum in Frisco, Texas.
Seattle Times news services
